The rapid evolution of large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT developed by OpenAI, has significantly impacted various fields, including scientific writing in Orthopaedics & Traumatology research. LLMs, which rely on vast amounts of textual data to generate coherent and contextually relevant text, have been increasingly integrated into scientific writing processes . The study by Maroteau et al. (2023) highlights this growing impact, revealing a notable increase in AI-generated content in articles submitted to the Orthopaedics & Traumatology: Surgery & Research journal, with suspected AI usage rising from 9.4% in 2022 to 12.6% in 2023 .

Historically, artificial intelligence has been employed in scientific writing to enhance productivity and streamline research processes, particularly in fields like clinical decision support, medical imaging analysis, and drug development . The introduction of LLMs, however, has added a new dimension to this landscape. These models, trained on vast corpora of text, can generate new content by mimicking patterns and structures from their training data . This capability raises questions about the originality of AI-generated text and its potential to blur the lines between paraphrasing and plagiarism . The study by Maroteau et al. (2023) identifies the year of submission and geographic origin as significant risk factors for higher AI usage, with Asian authors and 2023 entries showing a higher prevalence of AI-generated content . Specifically, articles from Asia had a higher proportion of suspected AI rates >20% compared to other regions, with an odds ratio of 1.79 [95% CI: 1.03–3.11] .

While LLMs have the potential to enhance research productivity by accelerating manuscript preparation and assisting in writing, they also pose ethical challenges, particularly regarding authorship and the originality of scientific content . The study emphasizes the importance of developing guidelines for AI-assisted writing to address these issues, including proper attribution to AI tools and defining the contributions of human researchers . As Gilat and Cole (2023) discuss, the future of scientific writing, reviewing, and editing will be significantly influenced by AI, necessitating a reevaluation of authorship norms and ethical considerations .

The study by Maroteau et al. (2023) serves as a call to action for stakeholders to establish transparent disclosure practices and develop robust guidelines for the responsible integration of LLMs in scientific writing . As the field of Orthopaedics & Traumatology continues to evolve, understanding the role of AI in scientific writing will be crucial for maintaining the integrity of research. The study also highlights the limitations of current AI detection tools, such as ZeroGPT, which provide only an estimated AI usage rate and may have a margin of error . This underscores the need for more precise tools to detect AI use in writing and to establish clear guidelines for AI-assisted writing . As Weaver and McAlister (2023) suggest, LLMs could be seen as "the emperor's new clothes," raising questions about the originality and authenticity of AI-generated content in scientific writing .

This additional analysis aimed to identify articles where the use of LLM was potentially more pronounced and to assess whether these had increased in number between 2022 and 2023.

For articles with a higher rate of suspectedAI use (>10 and >20%), a secondary analysis was carried out to identify risk factors for LLM use. The geographical origin of the corresponding author, the type of article and the year of submission (2022/2023) were evaluated as independent risk factors for AI use in the writing of a scientific article.

2.4. Statistics

Statistical analyzes were performed using Microsoft Excel (Microsoft Corporation) and SPSS (version 23.0; IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows) software. The quantitative variables were presented in the form of mean and range (standard deviation, minimum–maximum), while the qualitative variables were presented in the form of numbers and percentages. The normality of the data distribution was assessed using the Shapiro-Wilk's test. The comparison of quantitative variables was carried out using the Student's t test, and qualitative variables using the Chi2 test or Fisher's exact test, depending on the distribution of the data. A univariate analysis was carried out using a Chi2 test of independence in order to evaluate the risk factors for a supposed AI rate >10 and >20% with calculation of the odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence interval (CI). The statistical significance threshold was set at 5%.

This study has some limitations. One of them is the difficulty of detecting LLM use. Although the ZeroGPT tool was used for detection, the extent of LLM use in article writing remains difficult to ascertain. Furthermore, the ZeroGPT detection score is only an estimate of the AI rate, and there may be a margin of error in these scores, which was not possible to calculate in this instance, since the actual rate ofAI use was not known.Although, not being blinded to the true rate of AI use would have constituted a major bias in this study. To date,there is no scientific evaluation ofthis detection software, while a multitude of this software has developed in parallel with the improvement of LLM. The reliability of detection scores also depends on the sample size of the articles analyzed. Another limitation of this study is the wide variety of LLM available, each with its own characteristics and capabilities. This variety makes it difficult to accurately detect the use of these models in writing articles. Furthermore, it is not possible to determine which LLM was used in writing a particular article. While we have observed an increase in the assumed average AI rate, it is difficult to determine whether AI use has been extensive or limited. Some uses may be more subtle, for example to generate a first draft or to help formulate certain parts of the article. In other cases, AI may have been used more extensively, to generate the majority of the article text. Reasonable AI use is not necessarily harmful to scientific research or writing, but this leads to questioning the definition of "reasonable". The significant AI rates of >10 and 20% are cut-offs, which were chosen arbitrarily for the evaluation of risk factors for greater supposed AI use. Indeed, there is not yet a rate of "acceptable" AI in the literature. In all cases, this made it possible to rule out probable false positives with supposed AI rates <10%. Finally, despite the analysis of more than nearly 400 articles, subgroup statistical analysis induces a risk of mathematical bias due to the presence of a sample that is too small to ensure the robustness of certain statistical tests (e.g., Chi2 test).

Since the launch of ChatGPT 3.5, a significant increase in the use of LLM for articles submitted in English to OTSR over the same period (2022 versus 2023) has been observed. Finally, all articles suspected of more than 10% AI use were checked a second time to limit the risk of error.

When carrying out this study, after the authors had completed writing the article, optimization was carried out using ChatGPT. This optimization was carried out for the beginning of the introduction and the "strengths and limits" paragraph of the section 4. Although ZeroGPT partially detected these two optimized paragraphs, an unoptimized paragraph, in the section 3, was also considered suspicious. The assumed AI rate for our article was 7.5%. This observation once again highlights the difficulties in detecting LLM and the lack of precision amongst the tools currently available.

5. Conclusion

In conclusion, the role of LLM in scientific writing introduces a new degree of complexity to the elements of originality and plagiarism [7,9,12]. As Weaver and McAlister [22] suggested, LLM could be considered "the emperor's new clothes" in a process of imitation or derivation influenced by a flow of scientific creation. However, this does not diminish the value or importance of the creative process, nor does it undermine the potential of individuals to produce truly original work that pushes the boundaries of what is known and inspires new ways of thinking [23].

The rise of artificial intelligence (AI) amongst the medical fields is undeniable. It is currently implemented and refined for clinical decision support, medical imaging analysis and new drug development [1–7]. Recently, the world of AI has produced a dialogue agent, ChatGPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer), designed by OpenAI(San Francisco, Ca, USA) and existing since 2018 while being based on the latest version of the language model, GPT4 [8,9]. Large language models (LLM) refer to language processing that relies on enormous amounts of textual data (articles, dialogues, etc.), which allows these technologies to generate words and meaningful sentences adapted to the context [10]. Coupled with AI, this chatbot has the ability to interpret and generate text precisely and clearly on demand [9]. Its versatility allows it to write scientific articles in their entirety [11–13]. Its use in the context of writing original articles then raises the question of the originality and authorship of the text proposed to a reading committee that does not have a reliable and referenced tool for the detection of AI. It is therefore likely that an increasing number of scientific articles are submitted to Orthopaedics & Traumatology: Surgery & Research in "collaboration" with LLM, but this data has not been precisely evaluated.

Therefore, a retrospective study was carried out to evaluate the impact of LLMs on articles submitted to OTSR before and after the launch of ChatGPT version 3.5, in November 2022. This study aimed to address the following: identify the presence of text generated by LLM before and after the popularization of ChatGPT in articles submitted in OTSR; determine if the type of article, the year of submission and the country of origin influenced the proportion of text generated at least in part by LLM.

The rapid evolution and increasing application of large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT, have significantly impacted scientific writing, particularly in specialized fields like Orthopaedics and Traumatology. This section aims to explore the implications of LLMs on scientific originality, authorship norms, and the effectiveness of AI detection tools, while also addressing ethical considerations and proposing recommendations for future research and policy.

Examination of Scientific Originality

The integration of LLMs in scientific writing has led to a noticeable increase in AI-generated content. A retrospective study by Maroteau et al. (2023) highlighted a rise in AI-generated content in articles submitted to the Orthopaedics & Traumatology: Surgery & Research journal, with AI usage increasing from 9.4% in 2022 to 12.6% in 2023 . This trend raises concerns about the potential impact on scientific originality, as LLMs can generate text that may blur the lines between original research and AI-generated content. The use of AI in scientific writing also presents ethical dilemmas, particularly regarding authorship attribution. The study by Maroteau et al. highlights the need for clear guidelines on how to attribute contributions made by AI tools like ChatGPT, especially when they play a significant role in generating text . This is crucial in maintaining the integrity of scientific authorship and ensuring that human researchers receive appropriate credit for their work. Additionally, the study found that AI-generated content in orthopaedic articles increased from 9.4% in 2022 to 12.6% in 2023, with a notable increase in submissions from Asian authors . This suggests a growing reliance on AI tools in scientific writing, which may have implications for authorship norms and the perception of originality in research.

Assessing AI Detection Tools

The increasing use of LLMs in scientific writing necessitates the development of effective detection tools to ensure the integrity of scientific publications. Maroteau et al. employed the ZeroGPT tool to estimate AI usage in 390 articles, revealing a significant increase in AI-generated content in 2023 compared to 2022 . This highlights the need for robust detection mechanisms to identify AI-generated text and maintain the integrity of scientific literature. The study by Macken et al. also emphasizes the importance of statistical rigor in scientific research, which is crucial for evaluating the effectiveness of AI detection tools.

Focus on Orthopaedics and Traumatology Research

The impact of LLMs on orthopaedic research is particularly significant, as highlighted in the studies by Macken et al. and Merolla et al. . Both studies focus on the use of biologic increased-offset reverse shoulder arthroplasty (BIO-RSA) and metal-augmented baseplates (MIO-RSA) in treating shoulder osteoarthritis with multiplanar glenoid deformities. The findings from these studies suggest that while both BIO-RSA and MIO-RSA provide stable initial fixation and similar clinical outcomes, there are concerns about the long-term viability of bone grafts in BIO-RSA patients . This highlights the importance of considering the specific context of orthopaedics and traumatology when assessing the impact of LLMs on scientific research.

Ethical Implications and Recommendations

The use of LLMs in scientific writing raises several ethical considerations, particularly regarding the attribution of authorship and the potential for AI-generated content to be mistaken for original research. Maroteau et al. highlight the need for clear guidelines on the use of AI tools in scientific writing, especially given the significant increase in AI-generated content in recent years. In light of the findings from the referenced studies, it is crucial for stakeholders, including journal editors, researchers, and professional bodies, to establish clear guidelines on the use of AI tools in scientific writing. Nevertheless, other studies highlighted a higher rate of graft resorption, scapular notching, and baseplate loosening, thus creating concerns about the durability of this procedure.21 Metal-augmented glenoid components (metallic increased-offset [MIO-RSA]) were proposed as a suitable alternative to BIO-RSA, correcting glenoid orientation and restoring the joint line using a metal baseplate support.35 Researchers supporting the BIO-RSA criticized metalaugmented glenoid components, because they would not allow a multiplanar correction and moreover increasing the moment arm at the bone-baseplate interface.8 On the other side, recent clinical investigations have fostered the use of MIO-RSA, reporting satisfactory clinical outcomes, also demonstrating their ability to correct the glenoid deformity.24,28,34 The choice of bone or metallic augmentation becomes particularly important in type E2/E3 and B2/B3 glenoid deformities, where the pathoanatomic feature and erosion orientation require higher volume of bone removal using standard baseplate design.1,35 A recent randomized clinical trial, comparing BIO-RSA and metal augments in RSA with curved onlay humeral component, demonstrated that both systems provide stable initial fixation and similar clinical outcomes.34

In this study, we tested 2 hypotheses: (1) metalaugmented baseplates prevent the medialization of the joint line and preserve glenoid bone stock similarly to BIO-RSA; (2) bone graft viability and healing in BIO-RSA patients is impaired over time, thus compromising baseplate fixation and stability.

Materials and methods

This was a retrospective analysis of data collected from January 2016 to December 2018. Eighty-four consecutive patients who underwent RSA with glenoid lateralization using bone (BIO-RSA group) or metal-augmented baseplate (MIO-RSA group) were enrolled in the study. Two different glenoid implant models were used: Aequalis Ascend Flex Reverse II in the BIO-RSA group and Aequalis Ascend Flex Perform in the MIO-RSA group (Wright Medical, Memphis, TN, USA). In both groups the same curved-stem with onlay humeral component was implanted. The study involved 2 orthopedic units (Shoulder and Elbow Unit of ''Cervesi'' Hospital, Cattolica, Italy, and the Orthopaedic and Traumatology Unit, Modena Polyclinic, Modena, Italy). Patients with a preoperative diagnosis of primary osteoarthritis or cuff tear arthropathy and a minimum follow-up of 24 months were included. There were no specific exclusion criteria. Using these parameters and a power of 0.8, a sample size of at least 44 subjects (22 per group) was required. Of the 84 patients who were invited, 1 declined to attend the study because of logistic problems and 2 had incomplete clinical and radiographic data, leaving 81 patients (83 shoulders) in the study with complete clinical and radiographic data. Te improvement from pre- to postoperative measurements was compared using paired Wilcoxon signed-rank tests. For the comparisons between the two groups (BIO-RSA 38 versus RSA 42), unpaired tests were used. Tis was chosen over paired tests owing to the potential differences in response rate between the groups leading to unequal group sizes, the overall small cohort and limited population to draw from for patient matching leading to minimal dependence between matched cases [25, 26]. Chi-squared or Fisher exact tests were used for binary categorical variables and T-tests or Mann–Whitney U tests were used for continues variables.

For the radiological assessment, reliability between the frst two authors analysing the radiographs was assessed using the interclass correlation (ICC) for the angle measurements and Cohen's kappa (k) for the grades. An ICC of less than 0.50 was considered poor reliability, between 0.5 and 0.75 moderate reliability, between 0.75 and 0.9 good reliability and greater than 0.9 was considered excellent reliability. A Cohen's kappa of less than 0.20 was considered a slight agreement, between 0.21 and 0.40 fair, between 0.41 and 0.60 moderate, between 0.61 and 0.80 substantial and between 0.81 and 1.00 was considered almost perfect agreement [27].

To correct for multiple testing, p-values were adjusted using a Benjamini–Hochberg procedure. An adjusted p-value lower than 0.05 was considered statistically signifcant. A post-hoc power calculation was performed for the primary outcomes (rotational range of motion) using 0.05 as the signifcance level, a resulting power of>0.80 was considered sufcient. Surgical technique

In all cases a Delta Xtend prosthesis was used (DePuy Synthes, Raynham, USA) with a high-mobility polyethylene insert size 3. A deltopectoral approach was used for all BIO-RSA cases and an anterosuperior approach for all RSA cases. For BIO-RSA cases, a bone graft of approximately 1 cm in width was used, harvested from the resected humeral head when possible. Introduction: There has been an unprecedented rise is the use of artificial intelligence (AI) amongst medical fields. Recently, a dialogue agent called ChatGPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer) has grown in popularity through its use of large language models (LLM) to clearly and precisely generate text on demand. However, the impact of AI on the creation of scientific articles is remains unknown. A retrospective study was carried out with the aim of answering the following questions:identify the presence oftext generated by LLM before and after the increased usage of ChatGPT in articles submitted in OTSR; determine if the type of article, the year of submission, and the country of origin, influenced the proportion of text generated, at least in part by AI.

Material and methods: A total of 390 English articles were submitted to OTSR in January, February and March 2022 (n = 204) and over the same months of 2023 (n = 186) were analyzed. All articles were analyzed using the ZeroGPT tool, which provides an assumed rate of AI use expressed as a percentage. A comparison of the average rate of AI use was carried out between the articles submitted in 2022 and 2023. This comparison was repeated keeping only the articles with the highest percentage of suspected AI use (greater than 10 and 20%). A secondary analysis was carried out to identify risk factors for AI use. Results: The average percentage of suspected LLM use in the entire cohort was 11% ± 6, with 160 articles (41.0%) having a suspected AI rate greater than 10% and 61 (15.6%) with an assumed AI rate greater than 20%. A comparison between articles submitted in 2022 and 2023 revealed a significant increase in the use of these tools after the launch of ChatGPT 3.5 (9.4% in 2022 and 12.6% in 2023 [p = 0.004]). The number of articles with suspected AI rates of greater than 10 and 20% were significantly higher in 2023: >10%: 71 articles (34.8%) versus 89 articles (47.8%) (p = 0.008) and >20%: 21 articles (10.3%) versus 40 articles (21.5%) (p = 0.002). A risk factor analysis for LLLM use, demonstrated that authors of Asian geographic origin, and the submission year 2023 were associated with a higher rate of suspected AI use. An AI rate >20% was associated to Asian geographical origin with an odds ratio of 1.79 (95% CI: 1.03–3.11)(p = 0.029), while the year of submission being 2023 had an odds ratio of 1.7 (95% CI: 1.1–2.5) (p = 0.02).

Conclusion: This study highlights a significant increase in the use of LLM in the writing of articles submitted to the OTSR journal after the launch of ChatGPT 3.5. The increasing use of these models raises questions about originality and plagiarism in scientific research. AI offers creative opportunities but also raises ethical and methodological challenges.

This study has some limitations. One of them is the difficulty of detecting LLM use. Although the ZeroGPT tool was used for detection, the extent of LLM use in article writing remains difficult to ascertain. Furthermore, the ZeroGPT detection score is only an estimate of the AI rate, and there may be a margin of error in these scores, which was not possible to calculate in this instance, since the actual rate ofAI use was not known.Although, not being blinded to the true rate of AI use would have constituted a major bias in this study. To date,there is no scientific evaluation ofthis detection software, while a multitude of this software has developed in parallel with the improvement of LLM. The reliability of detection scores also depends on the sample size of the articles analyzed. Another limitation of this study is the wide variety of LLM available, each with its own characteristics and capabilities. This variety makes it difficult to accurately detect the use of these models in writing articles. Furthermore, it is not possible to determine which LLM was used in writing a particular article. While we have observed an increase in the assumed average AI rate, it is difficult to determine whether AI use has been extensive or limited. Some uses may be more subtle, for example to generate a first draft or to help formulate certain parts of the article. In other cases, AI may have been used more extensively, to generate the majority of the article text. Reasonable AI use is not necessarily harmful to scientific research or writing, but this leads to questioning the definition of "reasonable". The significant AI rates of >10 and 20% are cut-offs, which were chosen arbitrarily for the evaluation of risk factors for greater supposed AI use. Indeed, there is not yet a rate of "acceptable" AI in the literature. In all cases, this made it possible to rule out probable false positives with supposed AI rates <10%. Finally, despite the analysis of more than nearly 400 articles, subgroup statistical analysis induces a risk of mathematical bias due to the presence of a sample that is too small to ensure the robustness of certain statistical tests (e.g., Chi2 test).

This section discusses the main themes identified in the literature, including originality concerns, authorship and ethical issues, and the limitations of detection tools. It provides a comprehensive analysis of how LLMs are influencing scientific writing.

The integration of large language models (LLMs) into orthopaedic scientific writing has the potential to significantly influence the field, offering both opportunities and challenges. One of the primary benefits of AI-driven writing is the potential acceleration of manuscript preparation. As highlighted in Reference 1, the study by Macken et al. (2024) demonstrates that using a larger glenosphere in reverse shoulder arthroplasty (RSA) can provide comparable clinical, radiographic, and patient-reported outcomes to the more complex bony increased offset reverse shoulder arthroplasty (BIO-RSA) method . This suggests that AI tools could streamline the process of data analysis and manuscript drafting, allowing researchers to focus more on the scientific content and less on the mechanics of writing.

However, the adoption of AI in scientific writing also poses risks, particularly concerning the uniformity of scientific expression. The study by Merolla et al. (2023) discusses the challenges in maintaining diversity in research approaches, as seen in the comparison between BIO-RSA and metal-augmented baseplates (MIO-RSA) for shoulder osteoarthritis with multiplanar glenoid deformities . The potential for AI to standardize language and expression could lead to a homogenization of scientific literature, making it difficult to capture the unique nuances and innovative approaches that are crucial for advancing orthopaedic research. This concern is echoed in Reference 1:13, where the literature on BIO-RSA versus regular RSA shows contradictory results, emphasizing the need for careful interpretation and presentation of study findings.

Moreover, the impact of AI-driven writing on patient-oriented research is a critical consideration. Both studies highlight the importance of patient-reported outcomes in evaluating the success of orthopaedic procedures. Macken et al. (2024) found no significant differences in patient-reported outcomes between the two RSA methods, suggesting that AI could potentially enhance research productivity by efficiently analyzing and presenting such data . However, as noted in Reference 3:22, the viability of bone grafts in BIO-RSA patients may be compromised over time, raising concerns about the long-term stability of baseplate fixation. This underscores the need for AI tools to accurately capture and convey the complexities of patient outcomes and long-term implications.

In conclusion, while large language models offer promising opportunities for innovation and increased productivity in orthopaedic research, stakeholders must address the challenges of maintaining research diversity and ensuring the accurate representation of complex clinical outcomes. As suggested in Reference 1:16, prospective, randomized studies are necessary to confirm the findings and explore different prosthesis designs. Additionally, the development of larger glenospheres, as mentioned by Macken et al. (2024), could further enhance the field. Establishing guidelines for the transparent disclosure of AI use and balancing ethical considerations with technological benefits will be crucial for the responsible integration of LLMs in scientific writing. Future research should focus on refining AI governance in scientific publishing, particularly in orthopaedics, to ensure the continued advancement of the field.

Limitations

First, patients were identifed retrospectively, which may lead to a selection bias owing to the factors infuencing the decision to perform RSA or BIO-RSA. To address this shortcoming, patients were matched to create more comparable groups. Despite including age as a matching parameter, the age difered signifcantly between the groups, this may indicate that the RSA cohort was too small to achieve optimal matching. Tere was also a signifcant diference in follow-up time between the groups. Tis refects current practice as BIO-RSA is becoming increasingly popular in recent years. We intentionally selected a large time window to include a large cohort, which benefts the matching accuracy. Te diference in follow-up time may be a source of bias, however, a previous study found no signifcant changes in results after 1 year, which was the minimum follow-up in this study [8]. Furthermore, the approach difered between the groups (the anterosuperior approach was used for regular RSA and the deltopectoral approach for BIO-RSA); however, the approach did not infuence outcomes in previous studies [40, 41]. Second, bone graft healing and viability, and implant positioning is best assessed on computed tomography (CT) scans instead of radiographs. However, CT scans were not available in all patients. To maintain methodological consistency, we opted to assess these factors on radiographs in all patients. Last, the current cohort is too small to compare rare complications and revisions between the two groups.

Conclusions

At a minimum of 1 year follow-up, there was no diference in range of motion when comparing BIO-RSA with a size 38 glenosphere to RSA with a size 42 glenosphere. Similarly, no diferences were found in patient-reported and radiographic results, apart from a smaller inferior overhang in the BIO-RSA group. However, prospective, randomised studies are required to confrm the fndings, as well as including diferent prosthesis designs. Besides the similar clinical results found in this study, increasing the glenosphere size is less technically demanding and time consuming compared with BIO-RSA, less costly, and does not have technique-specifc complications, such as graft non-union and resorption. Tese fndings suggest that using a larger glenosphere size is a feasible and simple alternative to BIO-RSA for lateralising RSA. Te conclusions of this study may also add perspective for manufacturers to pursue development and research towards larger (i.e. 44–46 mm) glenospheres.
